0.title: Key 0: Key to major groups of freshwater invertebrates

a.label: Organism with hard shell

b.label: Organism without a hard shell

a.label: Head absent.  No fleshy lobes on either end of organism

b.label: With a head (may be very small or drawn into body)

a.label: More than six jointed legs

b.label: Six jointed legs or less

a.label: Wings, wing cases (hard plate-like modified forewings covering abdomen) or wing pads (very small underdeveloped wings on 2nd and 3rd thoracic segments) present

b.label: Wings, wing pads or wing cases absent

a.label: Wings or wing cases present

b.label: Wing pads present (but may be very small)

a.label: Wing cases with obvious split down the centre line of the body

b.label: Wing cases overlap, no obvious line down centre of body

a.label: Mouthparts modified into an extendable ‘mask’ ending in a large pair of jaws

b.label: Mouthparts not as above

a.label: Usually have 3 tails at the end of the abdomen, gills on sides or top of abdomen (some tails may have been lost – look for evidence at end of abdomen)

b.label: Two tail filaments, gills, if present, mainly under legs

a.label: No jointed legs, head may be hard to see or not visible

b.label: With Jointed legs, head easily seen

a.label: Abdomen ends in a pair of prolegs (short fleshy legs), each ending in a hook (may be difficult to see if specimen is contracted)

b.label: Abdomen not as above (may have prolegs, but if these are present, each ends in a pair of hooks)

a.label: Abdomen with long filaments down each side

b.label: Abdomen without long filaments

a.label: Abdomen ends in a single filament

b.label: Abdomen ends in three, two or no filaments or with a single claw

1.title: Key 1:  Key to Phylum Mollusca Families

a.label: Organism with one shell

b.label: Organism with two shells (bivalves)

a.label: Shell coiled

b.label: Shell not coiled, forming a low cone like a limpet shell

a.label: Shell coiled in a single plane, wheel shaped

b.label: Shell coiled in more than one plane (spiral)

a.label: Operculum (‘trap-door’ like structure in shell aperture) present (often drawn into shell – check by poking forceps or mounted needle into shell opening)

b.label: Operculum absent

a.label: Aperture large, over half of both shell height and width (see picture on right)

b.label: Aperture generally less than half the shell height or width

a.label: Shells broader than tall with hole visible in centre of shell next to aperture

b.label: Shells taller than broad

a.label: Shells often large (>20mm) with distinct banding pattern

b.label: Shells smaller and no banding pattern

a.label: Shell sinistral

b.label: Shell dextral

a.label: Shell marked with dark zig-zag lines

b.label: Shell not as above

a.label: Small (<25mm), nearly circular shells, mostly yellow or cream (some dark)

b.label: Large oval or elongated shells, typically dark

a.label: Sucker present on posterior, and usually anterior end

b.label: Sucker absent

a.label: Anterior sucker protrudes completely from the end of the body, four eyes in square arrangement

b.label: Anterior sucker at least partly merged with body

a.label: Eyes set towards the centre of the head (various numbers, see image)

b.label: Eyes set around the edges of the head (see image, check carefully around the side of head region)

a.label: Eight eyes (may be difficult to see)

b.label: Ten eyes

a.label: Large, pincer like front claws, >30mm long, like a mini lobster

b.label: Without large front claws

a.label: Body flattened from above (dorso-ventrally), woodlouse-like

b.label: Body flattened from the side (laterally)

4.title: Key 4:  Key to Order Coleoptera Families

a.label: Second part of legs modifies to form short ‘paddle blades’

b.label: Legs never as short ‘paddle blades’ (may be modified in other ways)

a.label: Hind legs with fringe of hair to aid swimming

b.label: No fringes of hair on hind legs

a.label: Base of hind legs covered by large plates

b.label: Base of hind legs not covered by plates i.e. you can see join with body

a.label: Obvious ‘shoulder’ between thorax and head, eyes protrude substantially from head

b.label: Head fits smoothly into thorax, eyes do not protrude significantly

a.label: Club-shaped antennae, underside covered in small hairs

b.label: Antennae without club at end, few or no hairs on underside of body

a.label: Head protrudes into a conspicuous snout

b.label: Head does not protrude into a snout

a.label: Antennae with segments of similar width

b.label: Antennae with wider segments near base (nearest head)

5.title: Key 5:  Key to Order Hemiptera Families

a.label: Obvious antennae (at lease as long as head)

b.label: No obvious antennae (can’t be seen from above)

a.label: Head over four times as long as wide, animal long and thin

b.label: Head as wide as long, not long and thin

a.label: Second and third pairs of legs close together and separate from front pair

b.label: All three pairs of legs roughly equally spaced

a.label: Longer than 4mm, orange stripe down each side of abdomen

b.label: Less than 4mm long, no orange stripe
b.path: Veliidae, Mesoveliidae, Hebridae and Saldidae (difficult to distinguish)

a.label: Animal with a single tail Often long)

b.label: Animal without a tail

a.label: Mouthparts blunt and rounded when viewed from below (see picture)

b.label: Mouthparts longer and needle-like

a.label: Body rounded when viewed from above and laterally flattened

b.label: Body more elongated, not laterally flattened

a.label: Eyes bright red, head sunk into thorax making a rounded outline

b.label: Eyes not red, head protrudes from outline of body

a.label: Hind limbs longer than other two pairs of legs

b.label: Hind limbs about the same size as others

6.title: Key 6:  Key to larval Odonata Families

a.label: Animals with three leaf-like tails at end of abdomen (may be missing)

b.label: Animals with five spines rather than tails at end of abdomen

a.label: Antennae long, first segment (nearest head) longer than rest combined

b.label: Antennae short, first segment shorter than rest combined

a.label: ‘Tails’ with extended filaments at end (not found in Scotland)

b.label: ‘Tails’ with short filaments at most

a.label: ‘Tails’ with black bands across length

b.label: ‘Tails’ without bands, or if bands present, only on half away from body

a.label: Labium (lower lip) flat, not covering face when seen from below

b.label: Labium triangular, covering face from below

a.label: Body wide (half the length of abdomen), antennae with four segments

b.label: Body narrower (less than half abdomen), antennae with 6-7 segments

a.label: Margins of labial palps with irregular teeth

b.label: Margins of labial palps not deeply serrated

7.title: Key 7:  Key to larval Ephemeroptera Families

a.label: First pair of gills reduced to filaments, others hidden under plates on upper part of abdomen

b.label: Most gills visible

a.label: Gills divided into two branches, each fringed with filaments

b.label: Gills rounded and plate-like or with one plate and filaments

a.label: Mandibles project beyond front of head

b.label: Mandibles do not project beyond front of head

a.label: Head is widest part of body; flattened from above (dorso-ventrally), gills usually consist of a flat plate and usually a separate tuft of filaments

b.label: Body widest at thorax; not flattened from above

a.label: Four pairs of plate-like gills largely on top of body, abdominal segments have paired spines

b.label: Six or seven pairs of gills (some may be lost), projecting from side of body

a.label: Gills either two tapering filaments, or a plate with a group of filaments. Tails as long or longer than body

b.label: Gills single pair of rounded plates, tails shorter than body

a.label: Hind corners of the last few abdominal segments drawn into obvious spines

b.label: Hind corners of last abdominal segments without spines

8.title: Key 8:  Key to larval Plecoptera Families

a.label: Ventral (lower) surface of last abdominal segment complete

b.label: Ventral surface of last abdominal segment reduced

a.label: Tufts of gills present on the side of the thorax

b.label: No gills on thorax

a.label: Last segment of maxillary palp verry narrow, at most ¼ of width of previous segment and at an angle to the previous one

b.label: Segments of maxillary palp gradually tapering in width

a.label: Second segment of tarsus much shorter than first (may appear absent i.e. you can only see two segments)

b.label: Second segment of tarsus at least as long as first segment

a.label: Hind legs reach beyond end of abdomen when stretched

b.label: Hind legs, when stretched, do not reach end of abdomen

a.label: Paraprocts longer than wide

b.label: Paraprocts wider than long

9.title: Key 9:  Key to larval Diptera Families

a.label: Animal has wing cases in thoracic region

b.label: Animal without obvious wing cases

a.label: Animal with two ‘fans’ of bristles on head end (may be folded up – look carefully to make sure) and generally swollen at opposite end

b.label: No ‘fans’ or bristles on head, although prolegs with hairs may be present

a.label: Animal with single extended breathing tube at end of abdomen

b.label: Animal without obvious breathing tube, but may have projections

a.label: Breathing tube short, thorax wider than abdomen

b.label: Breathing tube longer than rest of body, although may be contracted

a.label: Animal with two ‘tails’ or prolegs at end of abdomen

b.label: Animal without tails or prolegs, but may have numerous short projections

a.label: Prolegs on first thorax and last abdominal segments (may look like a single leg)

b.label: Two longer ‘tails’ at end of abdomen, prolegs on 4-7 segments

a.label: Very thin and thread-like body

b.label: Wider body, multiple projections at end of body

10.title: Key 10:  Key to larval Order Trichoptera Families

a.label: Larvae lacking a case; free living, typically associated with a fixed net, tube, or tunnel of silk and debris.  First abdominal segment without protuberances

b.label: Larvae living in a mobile (rarely fixed) case

a.label: Mesonotum and metanotum soft, without hard plate on top

b.label: Mesonotum and metanotum with hard plates (dark) like pronotum

a.label: Abdomen (and thorax) with tufted filamentous gills

b.label: Abdomen without gills

a.label: Labrum soft, pale and membranous, with a single straight edge

b.label: Labrum hardened (darker)

a.label: Anal prolegs long, hardened (darker) for half nearest claw

b.label: Anal prolegs short, hardened along whole length

a.label: Abdomen with tufted gills on ventral surface

b.label: Abdomen without gills

a.label: First abdominal segment without protuberances

b.label: First abdominal segment with two lateral (side) protuberances only

c.label: First abdominal segment with two lateral and one dorsal protuberance

a.label: Case tubular, made of brown translucent material

b.label: Case made of small stones, humped with a flat base

c.label: Case small (<8mm), flattened, seed or flask shape, made of chitin like material, sometimes covered by sand or algal filaments

a.label: Case a tube made of sand grains surrounded by a broad flange

b.label: Case a tube of sand grains; narrow and sealed by silk with a central hole

c.label: Case made of fine gravel or sand, with large stones down each side

d.label: Case made of various materials, or if made of sand, not as above

a.label: Mesonotum and metanotum membranous (soft)

b.label: Mesonotum at least partially hardened, metanotum with a few distinct separate sclerites (darkened plates on thorax)

c.label: Mesonotum as in b), metanotum without distinct sclerites

a.label: Posternal horn present

b.label: Posternal horn absent

a.label: Hind legs long, extending beyond other legs and twice their length

b.label: Hind legs not as in a)

a.label: Hind claw longer than tarsal segment and with sparse hairs

b.label: Hind claw shorter than tarsal segments, and often with a fringe of hairs
